Post a Comment Now. Comments Wed, 07 Mar 2007 10:42:00 GMT (1) In most states any changes in salary or wages must be provided in writing prior to the work being performed. So if you work for a bottom tier company that doesn't follow the law in providing it in writing you'll usually find out when you get your paycheck that they cut your pay. Point of fact you have now been notified in writing of the wage cut but you can file and claim the difference between the last paystub and this current one if it's the one the company has to rely on the paycheck as proof of notification in writing. Another words the proof in writing with the paycheck is good for future paychecks but not the one they do first. Thu, 08 Mar 2007 05:19:00 GMT (2) I don't know of any law in Missouri that requires vacation to be paid out at ANY specific rate. The standard is the current rate of pay, but in Missouri, you wouldn't even have to be paid your accrued vacation even if you terminated. So, my opinion would be that it would be legal to pay it at the prior rate, as there is now law requiring it be otherwise.
